content.question: Consider the graph of the function h given by <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>h</mi> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> <mo>=</mo> <msup> <mi>e</mi> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> <msup> <mi>x</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msup> </mrow> </msup> </mrow> <annotation>MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaGaamiAaiaacI cacaWG4bGaaiykaiabg2da9iaadwgadaahaaWcbeqaaiabgkHiTiaa dIhadaahaaadbeqaaiaaikdaaaaaaaaa@3E2A@</annotation> </semantics> </math> for 0 ≤ x < ∞. (a) Let R be the unbounded region in the first quadrant below the graph of h. Find the volume of the solid generated when R is revolved about the y-axis.

frqParts.text: Consider the graph of the function h given by <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>h</mi> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> <mo>=</mo> <msup> <mi>e</mi> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> <msup> <mi>x</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msup> </mrow> </msup> </mrow> <annotation>MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaGaamiAaiaacI cacaWG4bGaaiykaiabg2da9iaadwgadaahaaWcbeqaaiabgkHiTiaa dIhadaahaaadbeqaaiaaikdaaaaaaaaa@3E2A@</annotation> </semantics> </math> for 0 ≤ x < ∞. (a) Let R be the unbounded region in the first quadrant below the graph of h. Find the volume of the solid generated when R is revolved about the y-axis.
(b) Let A(w) be the area of the shaded rectangle shown in the figure above. Show that A(w) has its maximum value when w is the x-coordinate of the point of inflection of the graph of h.

topic.text: 5.5: Using the Candidates Test to Determine Absolute (Global) Extrema

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
